Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation2: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Story: I stared at the email from my mentor, the subject line clear: “Code Sample – Due in Three Days.” As a mentee, I knew how important it was to meet her expectations, to show I was committed and reliable. She’d spent time explaining the concepts, and I didn’t want to let her down. But as I opened my work calendar, a reminder popped up about the upcoming safety audit. The audit was still weeks away, but as the team’s engineer, I was responsible for ensuring every document was up to date and every process compliant. My manager had emphasized the importance of getting ahead, not waiting until the last minute. I felt the pressure mounting from both sides—my mentor’s trust in me, and my duty to my team and company. My mind raced, torn between diving into the code sample and starting the documentation updates. Both roles demanded my best, but I only had so much time and energy. I sat at my desk, heart pounding, wondering which responsibility I should tackle first.
